Authors:
Tassio Brito de Oliveira, Cene Gostincar, Nina
Gunde-Cimerman, Andre Rodrigues
Title:
Genome mining for peptidases in heat-tolerant and mesophilic
fungi and putative adaptations for thermostability
Keywords:
enzyme; protease; modeling; evolution; thermophilic fungi;
thermotolerant fungi
Abstract:
Genome mining has been applied as a new method to select
target and new enzymes in fungi. In the present study, we profiled the
genomes of heat-tolerant fungi and phylogenetically related mesophilic
species for genes encoding for peptidases. An extensive catalogue of
these enzymes was generated, ranging from 241 to 820 peptidase genes in
the genomes of 23 fungi. Thermophilic species presented the smallest
number of peptidases encoding genes in relation to mesophilic species,
the families with a greater number of genes were the most affected. The
peptidases in the genomes from mesophilic and thermophilic species were
compared and it was observed differences in thermophilic species in
comparison to mesophilic counterparts, at (i) the genome level: a great
reduction in the number of peptidases encoding genes that harbored
higher number of copies; (ii) at primary protein structure: shifts in
proportion of single or group of amino acids; and (iii) at the
three-dimensional structure: reduction in the number of internal
cavities. In regards to the amino acids composition, peptidases from
thermophilic species in relation to the mesophilic ones, contained a
larger proportion (p<0.05) of Ala, Glu, Gly, Pro, Arg and Val
residues and a decreased number of Cys, His, Ile, Lys, Met, Asn, Gln,
Ser, Thr and Trp residues. Moreover, an increase in the proportion of
hydrophobic and charged amino acids and a decrease in polar amino acids
were observed. Therefore, although thermophilic fungi present less genes
encoding for peptidases, these have adaptations that could play a role
in thermal resistance from genome to protein structure level.
